text: I've never done it in GA but I would not recommend first or last touch models. Multi-touch attribution is key to understanding how content supports the creation of revenue and which content is useful where in the buyer's journey. First / last touch are considered outdated today.

elements.text: I've never done it in GA but I would not recommend first or last touch models. Multi-touch attribution is key to understanding how content supports the creation of revenue and which content is useful where in the buyer's journey. First / last touch are considered outdated today.

text:
Content KPI Question fellow nerds:  We've got the following raw data metrics pulling from GA (first touch attribution currently).
• Avg. Time on Page - tracks time someone spent reading a blog - _nurture/engagement_ 
• Avg. Session Duration – tracks time someone spent anywhere on website in one session - _engagement_ 
• New Users - tracks net new readers - _views_ 
• Bounce Rate - tracks how often people land and leave a blog - _engagement_  
• Trial Started - tracks trials started - _conversion_
Does it look like i'm missing any key metrics to come up with some decent and actionable content KPI's?
What are KPI's do you use to measure content performance at each stage of the funnel?

elements.text: Content KPI Question fellow nerds:  We've got the following raw data metrics pulling from GA (first touch attribution currently).

New Users - tracks net new readers -

Bounce Rate - tracks how often people land and leave a blog -

Trial Started - tracks trials started -
conversion

Does it look like i'm missing any key metrics to come up with some decent and actionable content KPI's?
What are KPI's do you use to measure content performance at each stage of the funnel?

text: Hey <@U0192SVNRD4>, I think Wealthfront's help center is pretty good <https://support.wealthfront.com/hc/en-us> It's clearly laid out, and each section has different topics with specific articles. It fits a lot of information without feeling jumbled

text:
<@URA4VBQ2X> Thanks! Luckily we just did a full rebrand/site relaunch so that should hopefully be as good as we could get it to, and also is what gave us the technical infrastructure for google optimize.

In our case, running A/B tests even when it is somewhat subjective is helpful as our leadership team is really data-driven, but our content team is small (aka just me) so sometimes making the case for content audits/upgrades is hard versus net new content. But A/B test results provide data-driven results of what happens when we spend time making improvements to existing content!

elements.text:
Thanks! Luckily we just did a full rebrand/site relaunch so that should hopefully be as good as we could get it to, and also is what gave us the technical infrastructure for google optimize.

But A/B test results provide data-driven results of what happens when we spend time making improvements to existing content!

text:
TOFU, im looking at traffic, seo rankings/conversion rate, then any conversion rate--trials, blog subscribes, etc.

Have to be honest and say…im so focused on markteing metrics i often ignore things like bounce rate and time on page…im ener convinced the data is accurate from GA or that we’re interpreting the data right. Is a bad bounce rate fast if people find what they’re looking for a leave? Is longer on page/ multi-pages mean they’re not finding what they want? Not always a clear indiciator to me--but admittedly we don’t have a ton else for engagement except comments, social interaction, clicks, etc. Could be some engagement metrics there to help tell a full story.

text: Thanks for the insight Jill! And how big an impact on things do you think, first touch, last touch or multi-touch custom attribution modelling has on things? What model do you use?

elements.text: Thanks for the insight Jill! And how big an impact on things do you think, first touch, last touch or multi-touch custom attribution modelling has on things? What model do you use?

text: I'm basically focused on quality trial signups (as SaaS product), as my main OKRs, as well as as secondary metrics - traffic from highly converting countries, and rankings (but the latter secondary ones are not pursued fanatically). We make sure to focus on the thing that mostly moves the needle, which is quality trial signups. Quality - those users who perform a certain threshold of interactions with the product features after signup

text: <@UJHBBR59V> I actually can’t recall my current set up exactly, likely first touch. We have to source 40-ish% (inbound mtkg). But also have a blended goal between our outbound sales team and us that is called marketing assisted ops. Sometimes, an outbound rep takes our campaign or offer but finds the prospect. In those cases where it’s not a pure cold demo outreach, we share attribution, for a number of reasons that create more harmony and get us working together more. Not sure if that was helpful or confusing lol

elements.text: I actually can’t recall my current set up exactly, likely first touch. We have to source 40-ish% (inbound mtkg). In those cases where it’s not a pure cold demo outreach, we share attribution, for a number of reasons that create more harmony and get us working together more. Not sure if that was helpful or confusing lol

text: So first touch, us alone (marketing), or first touch outbound assisted (marketing offer + outbound outreach).

elements.text: So first touch, us alone (marketing), or first touch outbound assisted (marketing offer + outbound outreach).

text: No I get that, thanks Jill. Makes sense for your company. I'm trying to determine how far down this measurement rabbit hole it's worth it to go. We are just getting our content metric's stood up, I want to do it right, but I don't want to go crazy with it, there's diminishing returns with content metrics and the effort it takes to measure I find.

We are just getting our content metric's stood up, I want to do it right, but I don't want to go crazy with it, there's diminishing returns with content metrics and the effort it takes to measure I find.

text: I'm just making sure that we create content that brings leads. The query (searcher intent) should be directly satisfied by the solution the product offers. We don't get heaps of traffic, but it's converting. Well, at least until we manage to exhaust the topics, then we're going to move up the funnel and maybe update our OKRs :)

text:
Hi everyone. Could anyone please recommend content marketing/digital marketing agencies that work with freelance writers based outside the US/Canada.
I would love to work with an agency but the ones I've found so far either:
• Only pay via Paypal
• Don't work with writers outside the US
• Can't pay more than $0.07 per word
Thanks.

elements.text:

Only pay via Paypal
Don't work with writers outside the US
Can't pay more than $0.07 per word
Thanks.

text: <@UJHBBR59V> something I learned recently about google analytics time on page is that by default all bounced sessions/ sessions where the visitor only visits one page, time on page /session duration will show as zero seconds because there is no time stamp of a second page to subtract the time stamp of the first page viewed. There is probably a way to set up a custom event for when the browser page is closed or navigated away from so that you can get actual session duration for 1-page sessions. I mention this because it seems like blog post readers could often only read one page but still be very engaged. And if I’m on my phone and find a blog I want to read, most times I read a couple paragraphs then copy the url and save it in Notes app or send an email to myself with the link to read later.

There is probably a way to set up a custom event for when the browser page is closed or navigated away from so that you can get actual session duration for 1-page sessions. I mention this because it seems like blog post readers could often only read one page but still be very engaged. And if I’m on my phone and find a blog I want to read, most times I read a couple paragraphs then copy the url and save it in Notes app or send an email to myself with the link to read later.

text: Looking for advice on working with a affiliates. We recently had a loyalty program sign up to work with us but they require a one time set up fee. I know this isn't the norm but wondering if anyone has worked with a loyalty app through an affiliate program and saw great results... is it worth the additional cost? or nah?

text:
Hey all,

Quick question:

How do you manage a remote team and make sure that they’re working productively and efficiently?

elements.text:
Hey all,

Quick question:

How do you manage a remote team and make sure that they’re working productively and efficiently?

text: Personally, I hire people I trust, set clear expectations around outcomes/goals/deliverables, and don't sweat their hour-to-hour/day-to-day "productivity."  This philosophy was really driven home for me by spending a bunch of years as an IT management consultant and watching line managers obsessed with developer utilization rates drive talented people to the exits and burn their departments to the ground for fear that someone, somewhere might not be coding for 10 minutes.  If occasionally paying people to look at cat memes on Facebook is the price of avoiding that culture, I'll pay it :slightly_smiling_face:

If occasionally paying people to look at cat memes on Facebook is the price of avoiding that culture, I'll pay it
